this this researcher at the back here this lady is has fed the the chicken some corn what she's

that behavior over time the other researcher is introducing a slightly more difficult

in color so they're quite good at distinguishing this quite complex visual state and another thing that i'd like to point
out is what happens just here so the chicken has just been rewarded but the the researcher on the left has just
moved that pink dot off screen and the chicken it goes to peck where it thought the
pink dot was going to be so it's actually predicting into the future where it thinks the pink dot is
going to be okay so it's pretty sophisticated both sort of visually and temporally and this is the essence
of reinforcement learning what we're trying to do here is we're trying to reinforce behaviors and behaviors can be described by the
actions that are performed so that's reinforcement learning okay so question is is how far can you take this
with with birds well back in about 50 or 60 years ago there was a chap called rf skinner and

um you effectively encourage good behaviors you discourage bad behaviors and over time you generate these

so i i like to describe businesses as having three sort of key actions or be three key
business activities businesses have processes they have lots of processes they have decisions to be made less than
processes but there's still lots of decisions and then right at the top there are strategies company strategies obviously impact all
of the decisions and processes go on underneath you can kind of assign a value to each of those
activities so for example a process like connecting your laptop to the printer you would follow a series
of steps a checklist or something and uh you know that is a process fulfilled
and that has some value but it there's not much value to it if you're making a decision so usually
this is done by a human but if you're making a decision then decisions tend to have
more value attributed to them so for example if you are deciding whether someone should get a loan
or should get a new you know it's usually a customer-centric action
so so decisions tend to have a higher value attributed to them strategy right at the top
um this is something that is defined by very few people and can entirely define the success or failure of a business
so the value of that action is really really really important really valuable we can generally map
these business activities to different areas of the technology stack so
business processes are very well defined and encoded in software so a lot of software that is written is
purely just to encode some sort of business process um in in most of the software you write
you could probably imagine a a checklist or something to do the same thing but it just it's more
efficient to be able to do it in software same thing's true of of decisions we can use machine learning
to automate some of those decisions you know as time goes on and uh as as as ml adoption is is increasing
in industry these decisions are being more automated over time okay but the missing piece of the puzzle
up to now is the strategy part okay so so what is a strategy a strategy is effectively
a um a a a way of of making sequential decisions
over time okay so if if you had a business and this business decided to move into the retail market you know
there would have to be a sequence of actions a sequence of decisions over time in order to have a strategy
and reinforcement learning optimizes that strategy so you can see that that you know it is
kind of the missing piece of the puzzle in terms of the the operational business processes uh business activities sorry but also it
could potentially be the most valuable because it really is right at the top of the food chain you know
so people have been worried for a long time that you know uh machines are going to take over people's
jobs computers are going to take over people's jobs machine learning is going to take over people's jobs
well the the the the interesting thing now is that because reinforcement learning is at a
strategic level it's now reaching into the upper echelons of of a business you know this is like the
the cto cxo kind of positions that could technically be automated because we are automating their
strategies so um it's kind of kind of gone full scale throughout the business
and for obvious reasons you know it's basically for productivity uh and efficiency um uh
that's that's primarily what all of these different parts the the stacker are aiming for okay so what do you need
in order to use rl in a business problem so at the base of of reinforcement
learning the heart of it is a model a mathematical paradigm called a markov decision
process and technically it is a way of defining the probability
of transitioning from one state into another okay that's that's the sort
of the mathematical definition but i like to think of it as a way of modeling
problems a way of modeling business problems or not even business problems but a way of modeling problems
so that they can be solved by by reinforcement learning we've got two two entities here we've got an agent and
an environment so the agent is the thing that is actually making the decision okay so it's the chicken so let's let's
start a new example so imagine that you are learning to ride a bike in order to learn how to ride a bike um
you need to sit on the bike you know you are you are the agent in this case and you um you you uh
you define some actions that you can perform on an environment so let's first talk about the the the
actions so the actions could be uh turning the handlebars it could be pedaling
um it could be changing gears maybe you know they're all actions that you could do in an environment and the environment
in this case is the the ground that you're riding on it's the uh it's the things that you can
see it's the things you can hear it's things you can feel um you know things like that so it's it's everything
everything external to you basically and what happens is when an agent or when you um provide an
action to an environment then the state of that environment change
changes excuse me sorry but it's not and um so if i was to start pedaling on
my bike my perception of the environment the state of that i can observe of that
environment changes so i you know you you would see a different thing if you fell off your bike you you would
see it you would feel the the pain of the floor you know the state that you are observing
uh in that environment changes and this kind of forms this this infinite loop this this never stops you know
the the environment is pretty presenting some state to you um like what you can see you choose an
action it goes back to the environment it mutates the state of the environment again and then you and so on and so on
and so on so the the key the key to all of this is the sequential nature it's the it's the
infinite nature of of continuously making decisions in order to uh get to a point where you have an
optimal strategy not just a a one-hit kind of uh decision being made it's no
good just saying well at this moment in time i'm just going to turn my steering my handlebars 90 degrees because it may
not immediately cause any problem at that particular moment in time but you know in two
seconds down the line that's going to cause you to fall off your bike and get hurt okay so we need to find optimal
strategies to do this not not just single point you know machine learning style
single decisions and the key to all of this and and how reinforcement learning solves
this problem is through the addition of a reward okay and this this is one of the trickiest things to define in
a business problem actually because you need to effectively design the reward to solve
the particular problem that you're focusing on at the time so if you're learning to ride a bike
then what you could do is you could negatively reward your agent every time they fall off the bike or you
could positively reward the agent for staying on the bike but the definition of that reward is is
quite key because it kind of it kind of promotes certain behavior so for example if i just gave a very
small negative reward for falling off the bike that's almost saying that you know falling off a bike is not such a bad
thing you know it hurts a little bit but it's not too much whereas if we had a big negative reward
for falling off the bike then the agent and the model inside the agent is going to try as hard as it can
never to fall off again okay so it'll never explore those those actions again so you've got to be
really careful in that definition reward of the reward and there's a lot of research going on at the moment trying
to improve how how that gets defined

so if you're unfamiliar um adversarial attacks are an attempt to present um an algorithm with data
that is never observed before and sometimes when you when you provide some um some yeah certain data that it
hasn't observed before sometimes you get some strange results so in the machine learning case you know
you present like uh uh you present data to the algorithm um
and it might produce a very odd decision or a very odd prediction in the reinforcement learning case you
present a an adversarial strategy so the blue agent in this case has been trained
to always have a goalkeeper in the goal so what the red policy is trying now is
trying to see what happens when he just lays flat on the floor and it's learned that if it lays flat on
the floor the blue agent has no idea what to do it just stumbles around like a drunken person trying to kick a
ball and eventually it falls over okay
